name: Dipendra Prasad
content:
Dipendra Prasad (born 1960)[1] is an Indian mathematician.  He is a professor of mathematics at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay. He is a number theorist known for his work in the areas of automorphic representations and the Gan–Gross–Prasad conjecture.[2][3][4]
 Two of his siblings, Gopal Prasad and Shrawan Kumar, are also mathematicians.
 Prasad obtained his Bachelor's degree from the St. Xavier's College, Mumbai in 1978 before moving to the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur for a Masters which he completed in 1980.[citation needed] From 1980–1985, Prasad worked as a research scholar at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai (TIFR Mumbai).[5] He then completed his PhD under the supervision of Benedict Gross at Harvard, in 1989.[5][6]
 From 1989–1997, Prasad was a research assistant, fellow, and then reader at TIFR Mumbai.[5] From 1992–1993, Prasad was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study.[5] From 1994–2004, Prasad was an associate professor and then full professor at the Harish-Chandra Research Institute in Allahabad.[5] From 2004 until 2019, Prasad was a professor at TIFR Mumbai.[5] In 2019, Prasad moved to the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay.[7]
 In recognition of his contributions, the Government of India awarded him the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize in mathematical sciences for 2002. Apart from that he holds JC Bose fellowship awarded by the Department of Science and Technology, New Delhi.[8][failed verification] He is also a recipient of the Swarna Jayanti Fellowship in 1999.[1] He was Invited Speaker on the International Congress of Mathematicians 2018 in Rio de Janeiro in Section 7 (Lie Groups and Generalizations) with the talk 'Ext-analogues of branching laws'.

Dipendra Prasad (born 1960)[1] is an Indian mathematician.  He is a professor of mathematics at the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay. He is a number theorist known for his work in the areas of automorphic representations and the Gan–Gross–Prasad conjecture.[2][3][4]
Two of his siblings, Gopal Prasad and Shrawan Kumar, are also mathematicians.

Education[edit]
Prasad obtained his Bachelor's degree from the St. Xavier's College, Mumbai in 1978 before moving to the Indian Institute of Technology Kanpur for a Masters which he completed in 1980.[citation needed] From 1980–1985, Prasad worked as a research scholar at the Tata Institute of Fundamental Research, Mumbai (TIFR Mumbai).[5] He then completed his PhD under the supervision of Benedict Gross at Harvard, in 1989.[5][6]

Career[edit]
From 1989–1997, Prasad was a research assistant, fellow, and then reader at TIFR Mumbai.[5] From 1992–1993, Prasad was a member of the Institute for Advanced Study.[5] From 1994–2004, Prasad was an associate professor and then full professor at the Harish-Chandra Research Institute in Allahabad.[5] From 2004 until 2019, Prasad was a professor at TIFR Mumbai.[5] In 2019, Prasad moved to the Indian Institute of Technology Bombay.[7]

Awards[edit]
In recognition of his contributions, the Government of India awarded him the Shanti Swarup Bhatnagar Prize in mathematical sciences for 2002. Apart from that he holds JC Bose fellowship awarded by the Department of Science and Technology, New Delhi.[8][failed verification] He is also a recipient of the Swarna Jayanti Fellowship in 1999.[1] He was Invited Speaker on the International Congress of Mathematicians 2018 in Rio de Janeiro in Section 7 (Lie Groups and Generalizations) with the talk 'Ext-analogues of branching laws'.
